Variation Example: A fox lies in the road pretending to be dead. A fisherman throws him on his wagon which is full of fish. The fox throws the fish out of the wagon & jumps down after them. A wolf tries to imitate this & pretends to be dead, too. The fisherman catches him & beats him. In some variants one animal pretends to be dead in order to distract a man who is carrying a basket of food. Another animal steals the basket. Or an animal makes a hole in the basket so that the contents fall out.

A bear meets a fox who has caught a big load of fish. He asks him where he caught them, & the fox replies that he was fishing with his tail through a hole in the ice. He advises the bear to do likewise & the bear does. When the bear tries to pull his tail out of the ice (because men or dogs are attacking him), it is frozen in place. He runs away but leaves his tail behind.

A fox who has been tricked into losing his tail asks his companions to tie their tails together. When they run away suddenly, they pull each others’ tails off. The men in pursuit cannot tell which fox they were chasing, because now there are many foxes without tails. In some variants a fox who has lost his tail in a trap tries to convince other foxes to have theirs cut off. Often, he does not succeed.

A wolf sees a fox who has many fish, & would like to catch some himself. The fox tells him to hang a basket from his tail. The wolf does this. The basket is filled with water, or the fox fills it secretly with stones, so that the wolf cannot pull his tail out.

A bear gets a tail out of hemp to replace the tail he has lost. A fox provokes him to jump over a fire. Thus the new tail is burned (the bear himself is burned). The fox tells the bear to hold his burning tail up in the wind, but it only burns faster. The bear is injured or killed. In some variants, the fox convinces the bear to go to a smith to have a new tail welded on. The bear is thus severely injured.
A fox covers his head with a milky substance or dough & convinces a wolf that he has been so badly injured that his brains are coming out.

A fox convinces a wolf to go into a hen house & throw the chickens out to him. Then the fox tells the dogs & they attack the wolf. The fox runs away taking the chickens with him. When he meets the wolf later, the fox pretends that he has been attacked worse than the wolf.

A fox tricks an injured wolf into carry ing him on his back by pretending to be injured himself. While he is being carried, the fox says, “The sick animal carries the healthy one” (“The one who was beaten carries the one who was not.”) When the wolf asks about his chant, the fox changes the words around or threatens the wolf (by saying that dogs are chasing them).
A wolf chases a fox & is able to seize his leg. To get free the fox pretends that the wolf has only a tree root in his mouth, so the wolf lets go & seizes a tree root. The fox runs away.
A fox catches a crow & is about to eat it. The weak animal asks a question & the fox answers. Thus he releases the prey & it escapes.

Classifications: Animal Captor Talks with booty in his mouth
Variation Example: A wolf catches a goose & a fox catches a chicken. The fox asks the wolf something so that he opens his mouth & the goose is able to fly away. Then the wolf asks the fox, but the fox answers without losing his booty.

A bear & a fox wager as to which can name three trees first. The fox wins because the bear names three different varieties of the same tree. The fox names three different trees which can be pronounced more quickly. In some variants the devil & a man wager.

A fox tells a bear that he has painted the birds. The bear wants to be painted too, although the fox warns him that it will hurt. The fox has the bear fill a pit with pitch & lay wood over it. He ties the bear on top & sets the wood on fire. The bear is burned, wounded or killed. In some variants the fox hurts the bear in another way, promising to make him more beautiful or to cure him & then putting on him red-hot stones, drenching him with boiling water, shaving his head or tail, or putting out his eyes with a hot poker

Classifications: The Fox Trades the Burned Bones of the Bear for Reindeer
Variation Example: A fox gathers the burned skeleton of a bear & puts it in a sack. He rattles the bones as if they were money & trades the sack for a reindeer.

A fox & a bear work their land together & agree to share the profits. While the bear threshes the grain in the barn, the fox rests, saying he has to support the beams in the roof so that they will not fall on the bear. When they divide the harvest, the fox takes the grain & gives the bear the bigger pile of chaff. When their harvest is ground at the mill, the fox’s share sounds different from the bear’s. When the fox’s grain is cooked it looks light, but the bear’s looks dark. In order to convince the bear that all the grain tastes the same, the fox secretly takes a spoonful from the bear’s dish & pretends it is from his own. In some variants the animals have a race to determine who gets which part of the harvest.
A fox & a bear sleep together on the edge of a cliff. The fox pushes his companion over the edge so that he falls down & dies

Classifications: Theft of Food by Playing Godfater
Variation Example: A fox & a wolf live together. The fox pretends that he has been invited to be godfather at a baptism (invited to a funeral or wedding) but instead he secretly eats up the butter (honey) that he & the wolf have stored. This happens again (three times). When the wolf asks him the name of the baptized child, the fox makes up names that reflect the diminution of the stored food. When the wolf discovers the butter is missing he accuses the fox, who denies having taken it. The fox proposes a test to deter mine who took the butter: both of them will lie in the sun & after some time the butter will melt & appear. While the wolf sleeps, the fox smears butter on him & thus “proves” his guilt.

Classifications: Fox Entices Wolf Away from his Booty
Variation Example: This misc. type consists of various tales about a fox who entices a wolf away from his booty so the fox can eat it himself

Classifications: Animals Caught In a Pit Eat One Another Up
Variation Example: A number of animals go on a journey or pilgrimage together to seek their fortunes. They try to jump over a pit but fall into it instead. When they grow hungry, the fox proposes that they eat the one amongst them with the ugliest name, then who can sing highest or loudest , then who can howl the longest, then who is the youngest or the smallest. Thus all the animals are eaten one after another, until only two (fox & wolf) remain or only the fox is left.

Classifications: Animals Flee in Fear of the End of the World
Variation Example: A chicken is frightened by a nut that falls on its head, or another animal is frightened by a noise. The chicken thinks this is a sign of an approaching war (the end of the world, the sky is falling down), & flees in panic together with the rooster & they go to tell the king about the disaster. They meet other animals who come to share their fear & go along with them. The misunderstanding is cleared up, or the animals fall into a pit. In some variants they arrive at the fox’s den. The fox invites them inside & eats them.

A rooster wants to go to Rome in order to become pope. His wife accompanies him, along with more & more other animals. They meet the fox, who invites them to rest in his den. He asks them to sing & eats them one by one afterwards. Often the fox pretends to go on a pilgrimage to a convent. Other animals go along with him. The fox asks to hear their confessions or accuses them of sins which are characteristic of the different kinds of animals. Then the fox eats them as a punishment. In some variants the fox tells the rooster that he has become religious & repents his past actions, or he dresses as a nun. Then he reproaches the rooster with his sins (his polygamy) & offers to hear his confession. When the rooster comes near, the fox catches him & gobbles him up. Or, the rooster escapes by a ruse.

A fox & a wolf fall into a pit together & grow hungry. The fox has concealed under his body the entrails (brain, eye) of an animal that he had killed earlier, & begins to gnaw on them. He tells the wolf that he cut open his own belly & is eating his own entrails. When the wolf tries to copy this, he dies.

Classifications: Fox Induces Wolf to Impale Himself
Variation Example: A fox challenges a wolf to jump over a stake. The fox notices that the wolf jumps sideways, so he shows him how he should jump straight forward. Thus the wolf becomes impaled on the stake. The fox tells him he should make an effort to get off, which causes the wolf to be stuck even more firmly.

Classifications: The Fox Tricks the Wolf into Falling into a Pit
Variation Example: A fox entices a wolf to a pit. He dares the wolf to jump over the edge, or tells him there is food in the well. The wolf falls (jumps) in & is trapped. Or, the fox lures the wolf into a concealed trap.

Classifications: Fox Climbs from the Pit on the Wolf's Back
Variation Example: A fox jumps (falls) into a well & cannot get out by himself. He entices another animal to come down with him. When the wolf asks how they will be able to get out, the fox says they will help each other. He climbs up on the wolf’s back & gets out. On top of the well he mocks the wolf & does not help him out as he had promised

Classifications: The Wolf Descends into the Well in One Bucket & Rescues the Fox in the Other
Variation Example: A fox falls or jumps into a well because he is thirsty (is fleeing from someone, or wants to trick the wolf into coming down) & sits in a bucket. He persuades the wolf to get into the other bucket, & this lifts the fox’s bucket up to the top so he can get out. Often men find the wolf in the well & beat him.

Classifications: The Fox Plays Dead & is Thrown out of the Pit & Escapes
Variation Example: A fox (often together with one or more other animals) is caught in a trap (pit) & cannot get out. When the hunter comes, the fox pretends to be dead. The hunter takes him out of the trap and, thinking he will not move, lays him down. The fox runs away. Other animals try to imitate the fox’s trick & pretend to be dead, but the hunter is not fooled a second time.

Classifications: The Wolf Dives into the Water for Reflected Cheese
Variation Example: A wolf sees the moon reflected in water & thinks there is a cheese lying under the water. He jumps in to get it. Often another animal (the fox) persuades the wolf to do this. In some variants the animal tries to drink up the water in order to get some cheese that he supposes is under it. He bursts. Or, the fox plugs him with a stopper just before he would have burst, & removes it when they come to a party.

Classifications: Dog Drops His Meat for the Reflection
Variation Example: A dog swims across a river with a piece of meat in his mouth. When he sees his reflection, he thinks it is another dog with a bigger piece of meat. In an effort to take the meat from this dog, he dives after him (jumps into the water) & loses his own meat.

A monkey drops a lentil out of his hand. As he climbs down the tree to find it, he drops the other lentils which he also had in his hand. When he reaches the ground, he cannot find any of the lost lentils

Classifications: The Fox Asks the Wolf for Meat
Variation Example: A fox smells the meat that a wolf has caught, but gets nothing. He suggests to the wolf how to protect the meat from greedy neighbors, & steals it at night.

Classifications: The Fox Gets Bait from Trap by Luring Wolf into It
Variation Example: A fox finds a piece of meat by the roadside, but he is afraid that it might be a trap & does not eat it. When a wolf comes the fox tells him about the meat. The wolf goes to take it & falls into the trap. The fox is then able to eat the meat without danger. In many variants the fox pretends to be fasting & thus says that he cannot eat the meat. When he eats it afterwards, he tells the wolf that the time for fasting is over.

A fox (Rabbit) asks the children of the mother bear (wolf, fox, lioness) about their mother & says he would like to sleep with her. The mother bear overhears this & lies in wait for the fox so she can catch him. He slips between two trees but she is caught between them, & the fox rapes her. The fox uses mud to color himself black & comes back to the bear disguised as a monk. She asks him if he has seen the fox. He asks her if it was the fox who raped her, & she worries that all the animals already know what happened to her.

Classifications: The Fox as Nursemaid for the Mother Bear
Variation Example: This tale exists chiefly in three different forms: (1) A mother bear needs a nursemaid to take care of her children while she goes out hunting. Out of all (e.g. Rabbit, wolf, ox, fox) who apply, she chooses the fox (hyena). Each time she goes out he eats one of her children, but makes sure that she does not notice that they are missing. After the fox has eaten all of the children, he leaves. In north European variants the mother bear requires that the ap-plicants sing well, & thus chooses the fox. In a few variants the fox & the goose raise their children together & take turns minding them. The fox eats the goslings. (2) The applicants must sing to prove that they would be good hired mourners. While the mourning husband organizes the burial, the fox eats the corpse. (3) Instead of a nursemaid, a shepherd is needed for a herd of sheep. One after another, the sheep are eaten by the fox.

A man (fox) asks a bear (tiger) to help him fell a tree (split wood). The bear is to hold his claw on a part of the tree. The man removes a wedge he had put there, so that the two pieces of wood spring back together & the bear is caught. In some variants the bear asks the man for help, but the man says that the bear must help him first.

This tale exists chiefly in three different forms: (1) A wolf & a fox eat food that does not belong to them. The fox fixes a bell to the wolf so that, if anyone opens the door, they will be warned & be able to escape quickly. The wolf’s tail becomes caught in the bell cord (he is hung up on the cord). (2) A wolf forces a fox to give him food. The fox takes revenge by ringing a bell which betrays the wolf, or the wolf accidentally reveals himself by ringing a bell. (3) The animal that wolf & fox want to eat wears a bell, which the fox rings in order to betray the wolf.

Classifications: The Wolf Overeats in the Cellar
Variation Example: A fox (cat, jackal, hedgehog) convinces a wolf (polecat, hyena, antelope) to join him in breaking into a cellar (store-house, stable, kitchen, vineyard) to steal food. While they eat, the fox keeps checking to be sure that he still fits through the narrow exit. The wolf eats so much that he cannot leave. He is caught & beaten (killed). In early variants, a fox in a storehouse eats so much that he cannot leave. A weasel advises him to fast. Or, the fox pretends to be dead because he is so fat that he cannot leave the cellar without help. Thus he is able to escape.

Classifications: Bear Builds a House of Wood, the Fox of Ice
Variation Example: In the winter, a fox (wolf, bear) builds him self a fine house of ice. A Rabbit (wolf, fox, bear, sheep, goat) builds himself a house of wood (stone, iron, grass, wool). When summer comes, the fox’s house melts, & he goes to live in the Rabbit’s house. He gradually pushes the Rabbit out.

To settle a dispute (about their communal food supplies) a fox (hedgehog, sheep) proposes to a wolf that they swear on an iron trap (called Gospel) to tell the truth. This tale exists chiefly in four different forms: (1) The fox touches the trap delicately. The wolf hits it hard so its jaws snap together & catch him. (2) A hedgehog wants to swear on a tree with a trap that is called a judge. When the judge does not answer him, a wolf pushes the trap so hard that he is caught in it. (3) A wolf wants to skin a sheep, but a fox, who is the sheep’s friend, makes the wolf promise not to harm him. He swears by kissing a trap, & is caught in it. (4) A sheep proposes to swear on a bush in which a dog is hiding. The dog attacks the wolf.

Classifications: The Fox Hangs Onto the Horse's Tail
Variation Example: A fox (wolf, bear, monkey, several animals) runs into a seemingly-dead horse (donkey, dog) & (on the advice of another animal) wants to take the carcass home for food. He ties (bites) himself to the dead animal’s tail & starts to drag it home. The horse jumps up & runs away, dragging the fox to his master, who beats (kills) the fox. Or, the fox persuades the wolf to tie a rope around the wolf’s neck & the other end around the animal they want to eat. The wolf is strangled. Often the animal only pretends to be dead, in order to catch the fox. Sometimes the Rabbit witnesses the event & laughs so hard that his lip splits
